{{no footnotes|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Larry Joe Campbell | image = Larry Joe Campbell cropped.png | imagesize = | caption = Larry Joe Campbell, December 2009 | birth_name = Lawrence Joseph Campbell | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1970|11|29}} | birth_place = [[Cadillac, Michigan]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | occupation = Actor/Comedian | yearsactive = 1999â€“present | spouse = | children = }}
'''Lawrence Joseph Campbell''' (born November 29, 1970) is an American [[actor]] and [[comedian]] best known for his role as "Andy" on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] sitcom ''[[According to Jim]]''.
==Early life== Born in [[Cadillac, Michigan]], Campbell graduated high school from Pine River Area Schools and received a Bachelor of Applied Arts in theater at [[Central Michigan University]] and a Master of Arts in theater at [[Wayne State University]]. In 2005, Campbell returned to Central Michigan University to serve as the grand marshal of the homecoming parade.
==Career== His first high-profile TV guest star role probably was as "the fan" in a February 2000 episode of ''[[Friends]]''. The next year he was cast as "Andy" on ''[[According to Jim]]''. He has also appeared in movies, such as ''[[Wedding Crashers]]'', ''[[Showtime (film)|Showtime]]'', as "locker room cop #2," and in commercials, such as Ballpark hot dog commercials as "Frank," and a [[Public service announcement|PSA]] for the [[V-chip]] on ABC, as ''Jim'''s "Andy." In 2007, he appeared in two episodes of ''[[My Name Is Earl]]'' as Ron, a security prison guard. He also appeared as a cop on the take in a few episodes of ''[[Weeds (TV series)|Weeds]]''. Campbell also played Detective Crockers in the 2007 horror film [[Drive-Thru (film)|Drive-Thru]]. In the same year he also had a guest appearance on the show ''[[Supernatural (U.S. TV series)|Supernatural]]'' in the episode "[[Bedtime Stories (Supernatural)|Bedtime Stories]]".
Campbell performed [[Improvisational theatre|improvisational comedy]] with [[The Second City|the Second City Detroit]], and it was there where he was discovered when [[Bob Saget]] performed with the group and was impressed enough by Campbell to let his manager know about him. Campbell also dabbles in playwriting, he's a member of the comedy troupe the 313, and he has starred in a one-man play he wrote, ''Terry vs. the Towel Lady'' at [[Planet Ant]] in [[Hamtramck, Michigan]].
As of late, Campbell had a small participation on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]'s ''[[Weeds (TV series)|Weeds]]''. Larry also appeared as Pete Denham in the 2010 film "Killers" and as Vigs in "Fitful." Also, he appeared in the Disney Channel shows ''[[I Didn't Do It (TV Series)|I Didn't Do It]]'' as Deputy Doug, ''[[Good Luck Charlie]]'' as Hugo, ''[[Dog With a Blog]]'' as "The Hawk", ''[[Best Friends Whenever]]'' as Mr. Doyle, and [[CBS]]'s ''[[New Adventures of Old Christine]]'' and ''[[Rules of Engagement (TV series)|Rules of Engagement]]''. Campbell played the role of Hog Head in the 2011 film ''[[Hall Pass]]''.
He had a recurring role in the series ''[[The Protector (TV series)|The Protector]]''. In 2013, he began touring with a group of comedians known as "Jim Belushi and the Chicago Board of Comedy." The group consists of [[Jim Belushi|Belushi]], Campbell, Belushi's son [[Robert Belushi|Robert]], Jon Barinholtz and Brad Morris.
In 2015 Campbell appears in the Draft Kings commercial titled "The Sleeper".
In 2017 Campbell had a recurring role as Chief Engineer Newton in the first season of the Fox sci-fi TV series ''[[The Orville]]'', at the end of which his character was written out.
==References==
* Heidi Press, "Alumni Profile: According to Larry" ''Wayne State: The Magazine for Members of the WSU Alumni Association'' (Detroit) Fall 2006, p. 33
